title: Bladder Cancer Treatments: What to Know
author: Alyson Powell Key

content: If you have bladder cancer, there are several treatment options. Your doctor will help you decide which one is best for you.

Choosing the best treatment depends on a number of things, including your age, how much your cancer has spread (doctors call this your cancer "stage"), and any other health conditions you have, according to Charles Nguyen, MD, a medical oncologist at City of Hope in Orange County, California.
Categories of spread include:
Chemotherapy may be part of your treatment plan for bladder cancer. (Photo Credit: Peakstock/Shutterstock)

Many people with bladder cancer need surgery. But in some cases, it can’t remove all of the disease. So you’ll need other treatments along with, or instead of, an operation. These could include chemotherapy , radiation , and immunotherapy .
bullets: Superficial, where your cancer hasn't penetrated the muscle layer of your bladder.
Muscle-invasive, where cancer tumors penetrate your muscle layer.
Advanced or metastatic bladder cancer, meaning your cancer has spread beyond your bladder to areas (like your lymph nodes) and other organs (like your lungs).

Choosing the best treatment depends on a number of things, including your age, how much your cancer has spread (doctors call this your cancer "stage"), and any other health conditions you have, according to Charles Nguyen, MD, a medical oncologist at City of Hope in Orange County, California.
Categories of spread include:
associated_bullets: Superficial, where your cancer hasn't penetrated the muscle layer of your bladder.
Muscle-invasive, where cancer tumors penetrate your muscle layer.
Advanced or metastatic bladder cancer, meaning your cancer has spread beyond your bladder to areas (like your lymph nodes) and other organs (like your lungs).

content_blocks.text: Chemotherapy may be part of your treatment plan for bladder cancer. (Photo Credit: Peakstock/Shutterstock)

Many people with bladder cancer need surgery. But in some cases, it can’t remove all of the disease. So you’ll need other treatments along with, or instead of, an operation. These could include chemotherapy , radiation , and immunotherapy .

sections.heading: TURBT
content: Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT, also known as transurethral resection, or TUR) is the most common surgery for bladder cancer that’s in early stages. Doctors take samples of tissue from inside your bladder to find out if you have cancer there or your tumor has spread, or to take out a tumor.

content_blocks.text: Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT, also known as transurethral resection, or TUR) is the most common surgery for bladder cancer that’s in early stages. Doctors take samples of tissue from inside your bladder to find out if you have cancer there or your tumor has spread, or to take out a tumor.

content: You first may need a blood test and chest X-ray to make sure you’re healthy enough to have TUR surgery, but your surgeon won’t need to make a cut into your skin . They get to your bladder through your urethra, the tube that pee goes through as it passes out of your body.

Before the surgery, you’ll have either general anesthesia – which puts you to sleep – or regional anesthesia that numbs just the lower part of your body. The procedure starts once that medicine starts to work.

Your surgeon uses a special tool called a cystoscope, a long, thin, flexible tube that has a cutting tool, a light, and a camera at the end of it. They pass it through your urethra into your bladder. The camera shows the surgeon the inside of your bladder.

Doctors take samples of tissue from inside your bladder to find out if you have cancer there or your tumor has spread, or to take out a tumor.

content: You first may need a blood test and chest X-ray to make sure you’re healthy enough to have TUR surgery, but your surgeon won’t need to make a cut into your skin . They get to your bladder through your urethra, the tube that pee goes through as it passes out of your body.

Before the surgery, you’ll have either general anesthesia – which puts you to sleep – or regional anesthesia that numbs just the lower part of your body. The procedure starts once that medicine starts to work.

Your surgeon uses a special tool called a cystoscope, a long, thin, flexible tube that has a cutting tool, a light, and a camera at the end of it. They pass it through your urethra into your bladder. The camera shows the surgeon the inside of your bladder.

content_blocks.text: You first may need a blood test and chest X-ray to make sure you’re healthy enough to have TUR surgery, but your surgeon won’t need to make a cut into your skin . They get to your bladder through your urethra, the tube that pee goes through as it passes out of your body.

Before the surgery, you’ll have either general anesthesia – which puts you to sleep – or regional anesthesia that numbs just the lower part of your body. The procedure starts once that medicine starts to work.

Your surgeon uses a special tool called a cystoscope, a long, thin, flexible tube that has a cutting tool, a light, and a camera at the end of it. They pass it through your urethra into your bladder. The camera shows the surgeon the inside of your bladder.

content: Your doctor can also put a similar instrument called a resectoscope into your bladder through your urethra. It has a wire loop at the end.

content_blocks.text: Your doctor can also put a similar instrument called a resectoscope into your bladder through your urethra. It has a wire loop at the end.

content: They’ll use the cutting tool or the wire loop to take out tissues or tumors, and then they’ll use heat on the areas around the cut to stop the bleeding.
The tissue that’s taken out will be looked at under a microscope in a lab to see if it’s cancer.

After the procedure, you’ll have a tube in your bladder called a catheter. It takes pee out of your body and into a bag. You may need to have it in for a few days before you can go on your own. You can get up and walk when you have a catheter, but as the anesthesia wears off, it may feel uncomfortable.
Men sometimes feel pain at the tip of the penis afterward. If you do, be sure to let your doctor or nurse know. A numbing gel can help.
Many people go home the same day as the surgery. But if your tumor was large, you may need to stay in the hospital overnight.

content_blocks.text: They’ll use the cutting tool or the wire loop to take out tissues or tumors, and then they’ll use heat on the areas around the cut to stop the bleeding.
The tissue that’s taken out will be looked at under a microscope in a lab to see if it’s cancer.

After the procedure, you’ll have a tube in your bladder called a catheter. It takes pee out of your body and into a bag. You may need to have it in for a few days before you can go on your own. You can get up and walk when you have a catheter, but as the anesthesia wears off, it may feel uncomfortable.
Men sometimes feel pain at the tip of the penis afterward. If you do, be sure to let your doctor or nurse know. A numbing gel can help.
Many people go home the same day as the surgery. But if your tumor was large, you may need to stay in the hospital overnight.

content: You may see blood in your pee for up to three days after your surgery. Drink lots of fluid to help flush out your bladder – aim for eight to 10 glasses per day. This also can help keep an infection away.

Don’t lift anything heavy for two to three weeks after your surgery. Short walks are OK, but don’t do any intense exercise for four to six weeks. Talk with your doctor about when you can drive and go back to work.

Don’t lift anything heavy for two to three weeks after your surgery. Short walks are OK, but don’t do any intense exercise for four to six weeks. Talk with your doctor about when you can drive and go back to work.

sections.heading: Cystectomy
content: In this type of surgery, your doctor removes part of your bladder (a partial cystectomy) or all of it (a radical cystectomy).

If cancer has spread to the muscle layer of your bladder and is still small, your doctor may be able to perform a partial cystectomy. But most people who have cancer that has grown into the muscle of the bladder will need a more extensive surgery instead.

content: In this type of surgery, your doctor removes part of your bladder (a partial cystectomy) or all of it (a radical cystectomy).

If cancer has spread to the muscle layer of your bladder and is still small, your doctor may be able to perform a partial cystectomy. But most people who have cancer that has grown into the muscle of the bladder will need a more extensive surgery instead.

content_blocks.text: In this type of surgery, your doctor removes part of your bladder (a partial cystectomy) or all of it (a radical cystectomy).

If cancer has spread to the muscle layer of your bladder and is still small, your doctor may be able to perform a partial cystectomy. But most people who have cancer that has grown into the muscle of the bladder will need a more extensive surgery instead.

content: If the cancer is large or has spread to more than one part of your bladder, your doctor will likely remove the entire organ and the nearby lymph nodes . This is a radical cystectomy.

content_blocks.text: If the cancer is large or has spread to more than one part of your bladder, your doctor will likely remove the entire organ and the nearby lymph nodes . This is a radical cystectomy.

content: If your cancer has spread farther, the surgeon can also remove nearby reproductive organs and structures. In women, this can mean the uterus, cervix , part of the vagina , the ovaries, and the fallopian tubes . In men, this usually means the prostate gland and can also include the seminal vesicles and vas deferens.

For these procedures, you’ll be given medication so that you won’t be awake or feel any pain. You may have to stay in the hospital for up to a week afterward. Usually, you can go back to your normal routine in a few weeks.

content_blocks.text: If your cancer has spread farther, the surgeon can also remove nearby reproductive organs and structures. In women, this can mean the uterus, cervix , part of the vagina , the ovaries, and the fallopian tubes . In men, this usually means the prostate gland and can also include the seminal vesicles and vas deferens.

For these procedures, you’ll be given medication so that you won’t be awake or feel any pain. You may have to stay in the hospital for up to a week afterward. Usually, you can go back to your normal routine in a few weeks.

sections.heading: BCG Treatment for Bladder Cancer
content: Doctors use BCG treatment for some early-stage cancers. Also known as immunotherapy, it works by prompting your body's own immune system to target and attack cancer cells.

Doctors use a catheter to inject a liquid medication, a germ called Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG), into your bladder through a catheter. This germ is related to the one that causes tuberculosis , but it won't make you sick. The treatment draws your body’s immune cells to your bladder. There, they’re activated by the BCG and begin to fight the cancer cells. Nogapendekin alfa inbakicept (Anktiva), a medication that helps activate some of your body’s immune cells, can be used along with BCG if BCG alone doesn't work.

content_blocks.text: Doctors use BCG treatment for some early-stage cancers. Also known as immunotherapy, it works by prompting your body's own immune system to target and attack cancer cells.

There, they’re activated by the BCG and begin to fight the cancer cells. Nogapendekin alfa inbakicept (Anktiva), a medication that helps activate some of your body’s immune cells, can be used along with BCG if BCG alone doesn't work.

sections.heading: Intravesical Chemotherapy
content: This treatment also involves injecting medication (chemotherapy) into your bladder through a catheter to kill cancer cells, or into a vein if your cancer is at an advanced stage. Doctors often suggest this treatment when BCG treatment doesn't work or is unavailable. Drugs used in intravesical chemotherapy include:

sections.heading: Systemic Chemotherapy
content: Your doctor may give you chemo in pill form or through an IV. That means the medication travels through your bloodstream to other parts of your body. It can kill cancer cells that may have spread beyond your bladder.

sections.heading: Systemic Chemotherapy
content: Your doctor may give you chemo in pill form or through an IV. That means the medication travels through your bloodstream to other parts of your body. It can kill cancer cells that may have spread beyond your bladder.

content_blocks.text: Your doctor may give you chemo in pill form or through an IV. That means the medication travels through your bloodstream to other parts of your body. It can kill cancer cells that may have spread beyond your bladder.

content: You get chemotherapy in cycles, giving you time between treatments to recover. Each cycle usually lasts for a few weeks, and total treatment time may be several months.

If you’re having surgery, you’ll most likely get chemotherapy before the procedure. It can help shrink tumors, which makes them easier to remove and makes surgery safer. This also makes it less likely that the cancer will come back.

content_blocks.text: You get chemotherapy in cycles, giving you time between treatments to recover. Each cycle usually lasts for a few weeks, and total treatment time may be several months.

If you’re having surgery, you’ll most likely get chemotherapy before the procedure. It can help shrink tumors, which makes them easier to remove and makes surgery safer. This also makes it less likely that the cancer will come back.

content: Doctors often use the chemo drug cisplatin to treat the most common type of bladder cancer, called urothelial carcinoma . Cisplatin works by damaging the DNA of cancer cells so they can’t reproduce.
Cisplatin is often used along with other chemotherapy drugs. The most common combinations are:
If your kidneys don’t work well, you may get a different set of chemo drugs, such as carboplatin and either paclitaxel, gemcitabine, or docetaxel.

Your doctor can order chemo after surgery to kill any cancer cells that remain in your body but are too small or scattered for your surgeon to remove. It lowers the chance that your cancer will return.

Your doctor can order chemo after surgery to kill any cancer cells that remain in your body but are too small or scattered for your surgeon to remove. It lowers the chance that your cancer will return.

sections.heading: Radiation Therapy
content: This treatment involves using high-energy radiation to kill cancer cells. It’s a lot like getting an X-ray – only much stronger. It doesn’t hurt. You might need to get radiation five days a week for several weeks.

content_blocks.text: This treatment involves using high-energy radiation to kill cancer cells. It’s a lot like getting an X-ray – only much stronger. It doesn’t hurt. You might need to get radiation five days a week for several weeks.

content: Your doctor may recommend it for one of the following reasons:
bullets: You have early-stage cancer but can’t have surgery.
As a follow-up to TURBT or partial bladder removal surgery
To prevent or treat symptoms of advanced bladder cancer

content_blocks.text: Your doctor may recommend it for one of the following reasons:
associated_bullets: You have early-stage cancer but can’t have surgery.
As a follow-up to TURBT or partial bladder removal surgery
To prevent or treat symptoms of advanced bladder cancer

sections.heading: Chemoradiotherapy for Bladder Cancer
content: Chemoradiotherapy is when doctors use a mix of chemotherapy and radiation therapy to avoid surgery to remove the bladder. It can be a good option if you’re not healthy enough for surgery. In this case, you will likely take the chemo drug cisplatin by itself, cisplatin and fluorouracil, or mitomycin with fluorouracil.
You may also get chemotherapy and radiation together after surgery if your cancer has grown into the muscle layer of the bladder but hasn’t spread elsewhere.
If your cancer spreads after chemo, you can try other chemotherapy drugs or other types of medicine, like immunotherapy .

sections.heading: Immunotherapy for Bladder Cancer
content: This treatment uses your immune system to attack the cancer. It helps your immune system recognize cancer cells as dangers and launch a stronger response against them. That can shrink tumors or stop them from growing.

content_blocks.text: This treatment uses your immune system to attack the cancer. It helps your immune system recognize cancer cells as dangers and launch a stronger response against them. That can shrink tumors or stop them from growing.

content: Several immunotherapy drugs are used to treat bladder cancer that has spread. These drugs are called checkpoint inhibitors. To keep your immune system from attacking normal cells, your body uses proteins called checkpoints. They help the immune system tell if other cells are a normal part of your body and should be left alone or invaders that should be attacked.

Cancer cells can trick your immune system by binding to the cells that are supposed to fight it. When that happens, the checkpoint signals your body not to attack. A checkpoint inhibitor stops these cells from binding. That way, your immune system recognizes and targets the cancer.
The FDA has approved several immunotherapy drugs for people who have metastatic bladder cancer that got worse during chemo. These medications include:
These drugs are given every two to three weeks by infusion, which means through a tube (an IV) that goes into a vein.

content_blocks.text: Several immunotherapy drugs are used to treat bladder cancer that has spread. These drugs are called checkpoint inhibitors. To keep your immune system from attacking normal cells, your body uses proteins called checkpoints. They help the immune system tell if other cells are a normal part of your body and should be left alone or invaders that should be attacked.

Cancer cells can trick your immune system by binding to the cells that are supposed to fight it. When that happens, the checkpoint signals your body not to attack. A checkpoint inhibitor stops these cells from binding. That way, your immune system recognizes and targets the cancer.
The FDA has approved several immunotherapy drugs for people who have metastatic bladder cancer that got worse during chemo. These medications include:
These drugs are given every two to three weeks by infusion, which means through a tube (an IV) that goes into a vein.

content: One benefit of immunotherapy is it uses your body’s natural defenses. Once your immune system better recognizes cancer, it can continue to target those cells even if your treatment has ended.
Researchers are testing other potential immunotherapy drugs to see how well they work on their own and combined with other treatments.
They’re also testing combinations of immunotherapies. Early results showed that nivolumab combined with another drug, ipilimumab, worked in 26% to 38% of people who took them.
Studies are also looking at atezolizumab along with another checkpoint inhibitor called MTIG7192A.

Researchers are testing other potential immunotherapy drugs to see how well they work on their own and combined with other treatments.
They’re also testing combinations of immunotherapies. Early results showed that nivolumab combined with another drug, ipilimumab, worked in 26% to 38% of people who took them.
Studies are also looking at atezolizumab along with another checkpoint inhibitor called MTIG7192A.

sections.heading: Immunotherapy for Bladder Cancer
content: This treatment uses your immune system to attack the cancer. It helps your immune system recognize cancer cells as dangers and launch a stronger response against them. That can shrink tumors or stop them from growing.

The FDA has approved several immunotherapy drugs for people who have metastatic bladder cancer that got worse during chemo. These medications include:
These drugs are given every two to three weeks by infusion, which means through a tube (an IV) that goes into a vein.

sections.heading: Targeted Therapy
content: Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that pinpoints the changes within cells that cause them to become cancerous. It may be an option when bladder cancer doesn't respond to other treatments. Targeted therapy includes:
FGFR inhibitors

Fibroblast growth factor receptors (FGFRs) are growth-promoting proteins on bladder cancer cells. Drugs called FGFR inhibitors target gene changes within these cells that control how much of the FGFR protein your body makes. Erdafitinib (Balversa) is an FGFR inhibitor used to treat advanced bladder cancer.

content_blocks.text: Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that pinpoints the changes within cells that cause them to become cancerous. It may be an option when bladder cancer doesn't respond to other treatments. Targeted therapy includes:
FGFR inhibitors

Fibroblast growth factor receptors (FGFRs) are growth-promoting proteins on bladder cancer cells. Drugs called FGFR inhibitors target gene changes within these cells that control how much of the FGFR protein your body makes. Erdafitinib (Balversa) is an FGFR inhibitor used to treat advanced bladder cancer.

sections.heading: HER2-targeted therapies
content: HER2-targeted therapy, including antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs), is another type of targeted therapy. It links a chemotherapy drug to an antibody that specifically targets cancer cells. This allows the chemotherapy to be delivered directly to the cancer. Enfortumab vedotin (Padcev) is one ADC used for bladder cancer.

content_blocks.text: HER2-targeted therapy, including antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs), is another type of targeted therapy. It links a chemotherapy drug to an antibody that specifically targets cancer cells. This allows the chemotherapy to be delivered directly to the cancer. Enfortumab vedotin (Padcev) is one ADC used for bladder cancer.

sections.heading: Gene Therapy for Bladder Cancer
content: Gene therapy is a newer treatment option for bladder cancer. Your doctor may suggest it if you have high-risk, non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC), and BCG therapy isn't working. One FDA-approved gene therapy, nadofaragene firadenovec (Adstiladrin), delivers a gene directly into your bladder, which stimulates the body's cancer-fighting defenses.

content_blocks.text: Gene therapy is a newer treatment option for bladder cancer. Your doctor may suggest it if you have high-risk, non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC), and BCG therapy isn't working. One FDA-approved gene therapy, nadofaragene firadenovec (Adstiladrin), delivers a gene directly into your bladder, which stimulates the body's cancer-fighting defenses.

sections.heading: What Is the Latest Treatment for Bladder Cancer?
content: Scientists continue to discover new ways to treat bladder cancer. Here are a few promising treatments for the condition:
bullets: Adoptive cell therapy. This treatment involves isolating and modifying your immune cells to make them more able to fight cancer, then returning these cells to the body.

Antibody-drug conjugates. This targeted treatment combines a monoclonal antibody with a chemotherapy drug. The antibody identifies specific proteins on bladder cancer cells, delivering the chemotherapy drug directly to them while avoiding damage to healthy tissue.

Nanoparticle therapy. This treatment uses nanoparticles to enhance the delivery of drugs to bladder cancer cells. This method may offer benefits over traditional treatments, targeting cancer cells better and improving side effects, which could lead to better treatment results.

content_blocks.text: Scientists continue to discover new ways to treat bladder cancer. Here are a few promising treatments for the condition:
associated_bullets: Adoptive cell therapy. This treatment involves isolating and modifying your immune cells to make them more able to fight cancer, then returning these cells to the body.

Antibody-drug conjugates. This targeted treatment combines a monoclonal antibody with a chemotherapy drug. The antibody identifies specific proteins on bladder cancer cells, delivering the chemotherapy drug directly to them while avoiding damage to healthy tissue.

Nanoparticle therapy. This treatment uses nanoparticles to enhance the delivery of drugs to bladder cancer cells. This method may offer benefits over traditional treatments, targeting cancer cells better and improving side effects, which could lead to better treatment results.

sections.heading: Bladder cancer clinical trials
content: Major drug companies continually research and develop new medications and treatments for bladder cancer that must be shown to be safe and effective before doctors can prescribe them to patients. Through clinical trials , researchers test the effects of new drugs on a group of volunteers who have bladder cancer. Following a strict protocol and using carefully controlled conditions, researchers evaluate the drugs under development and measure how well the new drug can treat bladder cancer, its safety, and any possible side effects.

content: Some patients are reluctant to take part in clinical trials for fear of getting no treatment at all. But patients in clinical trials receive the most effective therapy currently available for the condition, or they may receive treatments that are being evaluated for future use. These bladder cancer drugs may even work better than current treatment. Comparing them in a clinical trial is the only way to find out.

content: "Always ask your oncologist for clinical trial opportunities," Nguyen says. "It's the best way to find new therapies."
Here’s where to find information about whether a bladder cancer clinical trial is right for you.
National Cancer Institute
This website lists more than 8,000 cancer clinical trials and explains what to do when you find one that you think is right for you.
ClinicalTrials.gov
This website offers up-to-date information on finding federally and privately supported clinical trials for cancer.
CenterWatch
This website lists industry-sponsored clinical trials that are actively recruiting patients.

sections.heading: Takeaways
bullets: You and your doctor will work together to find the best bladder cancer treatment option for you.
Treatment depends on your age, cancer stage (how far it has spread), and overall health.
TURBT is the most common treatment for early-stage bladder cancer.

Other options include surgically removing your bladder, and chemotherapy, radiation therapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, gene therapy, and promising new treatments such as adoptive cell therapy and nanoparticle therapy.

items: You and your doctor will work together to find the best bladder cancer treatment option for you.
Treatment depends on your age, cancer stage (how far it has spread), and overall health.
TURBT is the most common treatment for early-stage bladder cancer.

Other options include surgically removing your bladder, and chemotherapy, radiation therapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, gene therapy, and promising new treatments such as adoptive cell therapy and nanoparticle therapy.

sections.heading: Bladder Cancer Treatment FAQs
content: What's the most common treatment for bladder cancer ?
TURBT is the standard treatment for early-stage bladder cancer.
How many times can you have TURBT for bladder cancer ?

Your doctor may suggest a second TURBT a few weeks after the first to make sure they got all of your cancer. If your bladder cancer returns, they could do the procedure again. Scarring of your bladder is possible if you have TURBT several times, which can affect how much pee it holds.
What are the long-term side effects of BCG treatment for bladder cancer ?
Rarely, you may get a serious BCG infection. This tends to happen in people with a weakened immune system, which is why doctors don't usually suggest this treatment for them.
What are the different advanced bladder cancer treatments available?
Treatments for advanced bladder cancer include immunotherapy, chemotherapy, chemoradiotherapy, and cystectomy.

meta_description: Learn about bladder cancer diagnosis and treatments from the experts at WebMD.
